case_name: University of Kashmir v. Respondent No. 1

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1386 of 1972 was filed before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1386 of 1972. From the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal arises from Judgment and order dated 26th October 1971 of Jammu and Kashmir High Court in Writ Petition No. 36 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: From the Judgment and order dated the 26th October, 1971 of the Jammu and Kashmir High Court at Srinagar in Writ Petition No. 36 of 1970. S. Nariman,

facts.text: University of Kashmir terminated services of Professor (respondent) by resolution of its Council.

anchor.surface_text: issued a ukase by resolution of its Council, terminating the services of its Professor, the appellee, insufficiently aware of the kaleidoscopic legislative

facts.text: High Court declared the termination void and successful challenge by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: changes and crucial statutory consequences on the one hand and curiously indifferent to its own embarrassingly ambivalent dealings seemingly legitimising

facts.text: Jammu and Kashmir University Act, 2005 Samvat created University of Jammu and Kashmir.

anchor.surface_text: A chronological narration of the principal facts and events and legislative shifts and their implications must precede consideration of the legal contentions

facts.text: Respondent joined University as lecturer on contract basis in 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Several years later, the present respondent joined the University as a lecturer on contract basis, the law that governed his services being the provisions

facts.text: Jammu and Kashmir University Act, 1965 repealed previous Act and created Jammu and Kashmir Divisions.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, the Jammu and Kashmir University Act, 1965, was passed which, while repealing the previous Act, preserved and continued for the transitional

facts.text: Respondent appointed as Reader in September 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Anyway, the respondent who had joined in 1963 was appointed as Reader in September 1965, a few months after the 1965 Act came into force.

facts.text: Respondent appointed Professor by letter dated January 8, 1968 on probation for one year.

anchor.surface_text: A couple of years later the respondent registered an advance in his career and became Professor in the Post- Graduate Department of the University in the

facts.text: Probation period expired on December 14, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The one- year period of probation expired on December 14. 1968, but the Vice-Chancellor extended it .for one more year by order dated November 11, 1968.

facts.text: Vice-Chancellor extended probation by order dated November 11, 1968 for one more year.

anchor.surface_text: 1968, but the Vice-Chancellor extended it .for one more year by order dated November 11, 1968. This extension was confirmed by the meeting of the Central

facts.text: Central Council confirmed extension and resolved to charge-sheet respondent on June 26, 1969.

facts.text: Enquiry officer Shri J. N. Bhan submitted report on September 5, 1969 holding respondent guilty.

anchor.surface_text: An enquiry was held by an enquiry officer appointed in this behalf, Shri J. N. Bhan, who submitted his report on September 5, 1969 holding the respondent

facts.text: Jammu and Kashmir University Ordinance, 1969 promulgated on September 5, 1969 establishing separate universities.

anchor.surface_text: By accident it happens that on the same date, namely, September 5, 1969, the Jammu and Kashmir University Ordinance, 1969, was promulgated by the Governor

facts.text: Section 52(4) of 1969 Ordinance: contract teachers cease after 60 days unless Chancellor orders otherwise. No order issued.

anchor.surface_text: within 60 days from the commencement of the Ordinance the services of teachers employed on contract basis were to cease unless otherwise ordered by the Chancellor.

facts.text: Services of respondent ceased on November 5, 1969 by operation of s.52(4).

anchor.surface_text: Thus, by the inexorable operation of the calendar, on November 5, 1969, the respondent made a statutory exit from the employment of the Kashmir University.

facts.text: Vice-Chancellor issued show-cause notice on December 22, 1969 based on enquiry report.

anchor.surface_text: For, based on the enquiry report the Vice- Chancellor issued a show-cause notice on December 22, 1969, which elicited the respondents explanation on January

facts.text: Respondent gave explanation on January 31, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: 31, 1970. Together, all the materials were considered by the University Council at its meeting dated. July 7, 1970, where the decision was taken to remove

facts.text: University Council decided to remove respondent paying one month's salary on July 7, 1970.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no valid employment after November 5, 1969; no implied contract.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, by the inexorable operation of the calendar, on November 5, 1969, the respondent made a statutory exit from the employment of the Kashmir University.

facts.text: Supreme Court held termination invalid due to reliance on lapsed enquiry report; no right to reinstatement.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court noted; confirmed by statutes.

holdings.text: The respondent's services ceased on November 5, 1969 by operation of Section 52(4) of the 1969 Ordinance as no order was issued by the Chancellor extending the services.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, by the inexorable operation of the calendar, on November 5, 1969, the respondent made a statutory exit from the employment of the Kashmir University. This much even the respondent has reconciled himself to, and the High Court has accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.52(4) mandating cessation of contract teachers' services after 60 days absent Chancellor's order; no such order issued.

holdings.text: The respondent's appointment as Professor was on contract basis under the statutes of the 1965 Act continued by s.51 of the 1969 Ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 51 of the 1969 Ordinance all the statutes and regulations made under the Jammu and Kashmir University Act of 1965 and in force immediately before the commencement of this Ordinance shall so far as, may be consistent with the provisions of this Ordinance continue to be in force in each University after the commencement of this Ordinance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed by parties; confirmed by combined reading of 1965 Statute 1 requiring written contracts and s.51/59 continuing them consistently with new law.

holdings.text: Only the University Council is competent to appoint professors on the recommendation of the Selection Committee constituted under s.36.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the only body competent to appoint a professor, like the respondent, is the University Council, and even the Council shall make such appointments only on the recommendation of the Selection Committee created by s. 36. There is no case that the Selection Committee ever considered or recommended the respondent for appointment and there is no suggestion that the University Council appointed the respondent as professor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.22 vesting appointment powers exclusively in University Council on Selection Committee recommendation; no such process followed for respondent.

holdings.text: There was no implied contract or fresh appointment of the respondent after statutory cessation; doctrine of implied engagement cannot validate continuance outside statutory scheme.

anchor.surface_text: When a statute creates a body and vests it with authority and circumscribes its powers by specifying limitations, the doctrine of implied engagement de hors the provisions and powers under the Act would be subversive of the statutory scheme regarding appointments of officers and cannot be countenanced by the Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory scheme under s.22 limits appointments to Council on Selection Committee rec.; conduct cannot imply engagement de hors statute; ultra vires and subversive of scheme.

holdings.text: The enquiry commenced under 1965 Act was not continued or validated by 1969 Act/Ordinance; enquiry report falls to the ground and cannot be relied upon.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Solicitor-General fairly concedes that there was no provision in the 1969 Act which would continue or validate the enquiry ,commenced against the respondent by, Jammu and Kashmir University created by the 1965 Act. If so, the enquiry report falls to the ground vis-a-vis the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concession by ASG; no saving clause in new law for pending enquiries under old Act.

holdings.text: The termination order (Annexure A) is void as it relied on invalid lapsed enquiry report and casts stigma of guilt.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore clear in our minds that the termination of the services of the respondent was stricken by the vice of statutory violation. The respondent is perfectly right in contending that he has been considerably damnified in his standing and reputation by this order of the University.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reliance on enquiry report lacking legal force post-1969 law; order punitive with stigma, violating statutory conditions for termination.

holdings.text: Respondent has no right to reinstatement or continuance in service despite invalidity of termination order; High Court order quashed.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore declare that Annexure A is void but further hold that the respondent has no right to continue in service and the direction to him that he should leave his post as Professor and Head of the Post-Graduate History Department is good. The High Courts order of reinstatement is quashed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No subsisting employment after statutory cessation and lack of valid re-appointment; invalid termination does not revive non-existent right to service.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore declare that Annexure A is void but further hold that the respondent has numberright to companytinue in service and the direction to him that he should leave his post as Professor and Head of the Post-Graduate History Dep

outcome.relief_summary: Annexure A (termination order) declared void; no right to continue in service upheld; High Court's order of reinstatement quashed
directions: direction to leave the post as Professor and Head of the Post-Graduate History Department is good

anchor.surface_text: Thus, by the inexorable operation of the calendar, on November 5, 1969, the respondent made a statutory exit from the employment of the Kashmir University. This much even the respondent has reconciled himself to, and the High Court has accepted.

We, therefore declare that Annexure A is void but further hold that the respondent has numberright to companytinue in service and the direction to him that he should leave his post as Professor and Head of the Post-Graduate History Dep

edges.explanation: Holding h3 specifies the exclusive competence of the University Council for appointments, grounding the ultra vires concept c6 which applies to lack of proper appointment.
The holding circumscribing appointment power to the University Council grounds the Factum Valet concept's limitation on validating irregular acts under statutory constraints.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the only body competent to appoint a professor, like the respondent, is the University Council, and even the Council shall make such appointments only on the recommendation of the Selection Committee created by s. 36. There is no case that the Selection Committee ever considered or recommended the respondent for appointment and there is no suggestion that the University Council appointed the respondent as professor.

We, therefore declare that Annexure A is void but further hold that the respondent has numberright to companytinue in service and the direction to him that he should leave his post as Professor and Head of the Post-Graduate History Dep

anchor.surface_text: When a statute creates a body and vests it with authority and circumscribes its powers by specifying limitations, the doctrine of implied engagement de hors the provisions and powers under the Act would be subversive of the statutory scheme regarding appointments of officers and cannot be countenanced by the Court.

We, therefore declare that Annexure A is void but further hold that the respondent has numberright to companytinue in service and the direction to him that he should leave his post as Professor and Head of the Post-Graduate History Dep

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore clear in our minds that the termination of the services of the respondent was stricken by the vice of statutory violation.
